parent_formation: Comando Superiore Forze Armate Africa Settentrionale (North Africa Command)

commander.name: Unknown (not documented)
commander.notes: Commander's name not found in available sources for June 1940

75/27 Mod. 06 Field Gun.notes: II & III Gruppi, 45th CIRENE Artillery Regiment

100/17 Mod. 14 Howitzer.notes: I Gruppo, 45th CIRENE Artillery Regiment, Skoda-designed

81mm Mod. 35 Mortar.notes: 9 per infantry regiment (LXIII Battaglione Mortai Divisionale)

45mm Mod. 35 Brixia.notes: Light mortar, company level in infantry regiments

65/17 Mod. 13.notes: 4 per infantry regiment, support weapons companies

supply_status.notes: Metropolitan division permanently stationed in Libya since pre-war. Well-supplied at June 1940 entry into WWII, stationed in Eastern Cyrenaica defensive sector.

subordinate_units.notes: Attached from 1 March 1940, may not be fully integrated by June 1940

tactical_doctrine.role: Static defense of Eastern Cyrenaica sector, manning fortified positions along Egyptian border
special_capabilities: Metropolitan division with full peacetime training
Permanently stationed in Libya since pre-war period
Familiar with local terrain and defensive positions
known_issues: Binary structure (2 regiments) reduces combat power vs. pre-1939 ternary divisions
Dependent on animal transport for much logistics
Very weak anti-tank capability (only 8 x 47mm guns)
No armored fighting vehicles organic to division
Fascist Militia legion integration still incomplete in June 1940
Vulnerable to mobile warfare tactics employed by British in 1940-41
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Long-term desert garrison, equipped with tropical uniforms, experienced in desert logistics and water management, but lacking mechanization for mobile desert operations

special_rules: Desert Garrison: No penalties for desert operations
Limited Mobility: -2 to strategic movement, primarily foot-mobile
Weak AT Defense: -1 vs. armored attacks
Metropolitan Status: Better trained than colonial units, +1 morale vs. colonial divisions
Destroyed 1940-41: Division was destroyed during Operation Compass/Compass follow-on
historical_engagements: Division destroyed in first British offensive into Libya (1941)

source: TM-E 30-420 Handbook on Italian Military Forces (August 1943) - Section 51, Figure 5 (Binary division TO&E)
TM-E 30-420 - Section 54 (Truck-borne vs. standard infantry divisions)
Italian binary division organizational tables (TM 30-420 page 1100-1158)
Historical records: 63rd Cirene destroyed in 1941 British advance
known_gaps: Commander's name not found in any source (marked Unknown)
Exact headquarters location within Eastern Cyrenaica not specified
Precise vehicle operational rates estimated from standard Italian June 1940 status
Individual battalion compositions calculated from TM 30-420 binary division tables
Fascist Militia legion integration status unclear for June 1940 (attached March 1940)
No detailed equipment serial data available
Home station of 45th CIRENE Artillery Regiment given as Lecce (mainland Italy) in source
validation.notes: 63rd CIRENE Division was a Metropolitan Infantry Division permanently stationed in Libya (not a Colonial division despite location). Personnel totals calculated from TM 30-420 binary division organization (Figure 5: 12,169 total with Militia legion, 10,864 without). Division composition confirmed from USA HQ G-2 July 1943 document: 157th LIGURIA Infantry Regiment, 158th LIGURIA Infantry Regiment, 45th CIRENE Artillery Regiment (home station Lecce, Italy). Division followed standard Italian binary division structure implemented March 1940 with attached 2-battalion Fascist Militia legion. Vehicle counts estimated as lower than autotrasportabile divisions (this was a standard foot-mobile division). Artillery allocation standard for binary division: 36 field guns (24 x 75mm, 12 x 100mm). Division destroyed during Operation Compass and follow-on British offensive into Libya (December 1940 - February 1941). Confidence score 68% reflects good structural data from primary sources but missing commander identification and precise June 1940 operational details.
validation.data_quality_notes: This TO&E represents the division at Italy's entry into WWII (10 June 1940). The division had been stationed in Libya for extended period pre-war and was one of several metropolitan divisions defending Cyrenaica. Unlike autotrasportabile divisions (Brescia, Pavia, etc.), the Cirene was a standard binary infantry division with limited motor transport. Equipment allocations follow standard binary division tables from TM 30-420. The Fascist Militia legion (Legione CC.NN. Cirene) was theoretically attached from 1 March 1940, but integration may have been incomplete by June 1940. Division's ultimate fate (destruction in 1940-41) is well-documented but specific June 1940 operational status less detailed in sources.
